Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Functional Integration of Synthetic Kinases into Endogenous Signaling Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cells can acquire new genes by natural mechanisms (e.g. horizontal gene transfer) or by artificial means (e.g. genetic engineering). We are beginning to understand how newly-acquired genes are integrated into the host's genome, but the evolutionary mechanisms by which the proteins produced by these genes become functionally incorporated into the cell's regulatory networks remain largely unknown. In this project, synthetic biology and directed evolution approaches will be used to recreate and analyze in the laboratory this network rewiring process. Using yeast that have been engineered with signaling modules taken from the mammalian mitogen-activated protein kinase cascade, evolutionary strategies will be applied in the laboratory to reward individual yeast cells that acquire mutations resulting in functional utilization of these introduced mammalian proteins. During this selection process, genome sequencing will be performed to characterize the mutations that occur and to reconstruct the evolutionary processes that result in functional rewiring of the host's signaling networks.

Broader Impacts: The scientific principles underlying this research will be used to train graduate and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented minorities. Modules on evolution in synthetic biology will be added to an undergraduate course taught by the principal investigator. Undergraduates will also have the opportunity to learn about synthetic biology through the International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) competition. Additional outreach will be targeted to high school teachers and high school students through summer training programs. The insights gained from this project will have relevance for understanding the emergence of antibiotic resistance in microbes, the cultivation and properties of genetically modified crops, and the design of novel synthetic biology devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Horizontal gene transfer plays an important role in the evolution of gene regulatory networks in cells, particularly in microbes such as yeast and bacteria. While there is a growing body of work to explain how initially artificial genes are acquired and become integrated into the host’s genome, the evolutionary mechanisms by which the corresponding synthetic proteins become functionally incorporated into the cell’s regulatory networks and drive cell responses remain largely unknown.

The intellectual merit of this grant was to employ experimental approaches that would allow us to recreate and analyze this network rewiring process in the laboratory. We introduced synthetic enzymes into cells and then used accelerated laboratory evolution to alter the manner in which these synthetic enzymes regulate the behaviors of their host cells. Interestingly, we found that the dosage of these enzymes can sometimes play an important, yet non-intuitive, role in controlling how cells make decisions. Additionally, we constructed a system for continuous growth and evolution of our cells and then employed this system to selectively enrich for cells that have evolved to grow faster under constant environmental conditions. These faster-growing species will be the focus of our follow-on studies.

The broader impacts of this grant were to train graduate and undergraduate students in synthetic biology and protein engineering. The PI created a new graduate course at the University of Minnesota entitled ‘Systems and Synthetic Biology,’ which covers content directly relevant to the scientific principles of this grant. The PI has also served as a faculty co-advisor for an undergraduate synthetic biology team (iGEM) at the University of Minnesota in 2014, 2015, and 2016. This has involved training more than 25 students from four different colleges on campus, and in alignment with this grant, their projects have also entailed introduction of synthetic enzymes into microbes. Additionally, the students have participated in numerous outreach efforts to engage and educate the public about synthetic biology.
